answers.answer: Exercise usually has the potential to make your blood sugar dip, not increase, but read this article about monitoring blood sugar during exercise for more information. Hope it helps you!http://www.medhelp.org/diabetes/articles/Get-Ready-to-Exercise/1883You can also find this in the app by going to the home screen, and clicking the menu bar in the upper left corner. Tap Health Guide, then scroll to Move More. Scroll down for this and other articles related to diabetes and fitness.

HelloMany people with diabetes do find that exercise Can raise blood sugar,  particularly if the exercise is vigorous. Conversely you may also  low blood sugar several hours later.  Everyone is individual. Some people can v use a beta blocker to prevent the exercise vbb induce rise.  You can ask your doctor about this. Else may need to take medication / insulin prior to exercise.  This should also be discussed with your Dr.

question: Recently after working out my readings have been low 200s can the be because of the exercising
title: Can exercise make my blood glucose go high?
